stories.text:
I ask because I went through this process many times in my previous business, and the process was just incredibly complex and time-consuming. Our process went something like this:

1. Finding suitable users 2. Scheduling back and forth 3. Preparing for interview 4. Conducting interview 5. Analysing results

Now don't get wrong, the insights were useful, but the amount of effort you put in, related to the insights you get out just don't seem worth it.

Is this just me? Or has anyone else had a similar experience?
stories.title: Ask HN: What do people think of the user/customer interview process?
Show HN: Ethical Hacking, Network Attacks

stories.text:
I find the first hand story of how different architectural decisions turn out in real world scenarios are way more valuable than all the blogs out there writing about any new hot piece of code.

I recently bumped into the one by Etsy (http://codeascraft.etsy.com/) and I'm sure there are many others. I'm curious what you found interesting and even check regularly.
stories.title: Ask HN: What are some interesting “official development blogs” you like?
Show HN: I'm trying to bring Async to Django ORM
Web cache poisoning bug discovered in Symfony PHP framework
James Clark on How Ballerina Handles Network Interaction, Data, and Concurrency

stories.text:
Dear HN, I'm looking for a way to realize a graphics terminal for remotely working on a Linux server, i.e. I am looking for a low-cost hardware choice and an easy-to-set-up software solution (zero admin desired) for a set of boxes that are to connect to a central Linux server
for teaching purposes. What would people recommend? A Raspberry Pi + some Linux distribution featuring X11 R6, or a ready appliance? (Only free and open source software suggestions, please)
stories.title: Ask HN: Best low-cost, zero admin X terminal?
Ask HN: What is your favourite Chromium Browser?
